policies.title: Economic Freedom & Anti-Cronyism
policies.description: Breaking up the cozy relationship between government and big business benefits all Americans. Government should not pick winners and losers. These policies find support across the political spectrum and represent realistic starting points.

subPolicies.title: Medicare Competitive Bidding
problem: Medicare pays fixed prices set by formula, not market competition
Durable medical equipment costs 2-3x retail prices
No incentive for suppliers to compete on price
Taxpayers and beneficiaries pay inflated costs
Prior competitive bidding pilot saved 42% — then was ended due to industry lobbying
positions: Expand competitive bidding to all durable medical equipment
Apply competitive bidding principles to other Medicare purchases where feasible
Require transparent pricing data
Allow beneficiaries to shop and keep a portion of savings (reference pricing)

framing.forConservatives: Market competition, not government price-fixing. Let suppliers compete.
framing.forProgressives: Stop overpaying corporations. Save Medicare money for actual care.
framing.forEveryone: Why pay $500 for something that costs $100 at the store?

subPolicies.allies: Taxpayer advocates, fiscal conservatives, some healthcare reformers
subPolicies.opposition: Medical equipment suppliers, healthcare industry lobbyists

subPolicies.title: Occupational Licensing Reform
problem: 1 in 4 American workers now needs government permission to work (up from 1 in 20 in the 1950s)
Average license requires $267 in fees, 9 months of training, and an exam
Licenses don't transfer between states — blocks military spouses, movers
Primarily protects existing practitioners from competition, not consumers from harm
Barriers hit hardest for low-income workers, immigrants, and those with criminal records
positions: Universal recognition: Accept valid out-of-state licenses
Sunset reviews: Require periodic justification for all licensing requirements
Least restrictive means: Use certification, bonding, or inspection instead of licensing where possible
Right to earn a living: Require government to prove licensing is necessary, not the worker to prove they're qualified
Clean slate provisions: Remove licensing barriers for rehabilitated offenders in non-sensitive fields

framing.forConservatives: Free market. Right to earn a living. Get government out of the way.
framing.forProgressives: Licensing barriers hurt minorities, immigrants, and the poor. This is economic justice.
framing.forEveryone: You shouldn't need government permission to braid hair or arrange flowers.

subPolicies.allies: Institute for Justice, state policy think tanks, small business groups, workforce development organizations
subPolicies.opposition: Licensed professionals protecting their markets, some trade associations

subPolicies.title: Right to Repair
problem: Manufacturers use software locks, proprietary parts, and withheld documentation to block independent repair
John Deere tractors require dealer visits for basic repairs — farmers can't fix their own equipment
Apple and others void warranties for independent repairs and refuse parts to non-authorized shops
Medical devices locked so hospitals can't perform basic maintenance
Electronics designed with planned obsolescence — can't be economically repaired
positions: Require manufacturers to provide diagnostic tools, repair documentation, and replacement parts
Prohibit software locks that prevent repair
Prohibit voiding warranties solely because of independent repair
Apply to all product categories: agricultural equipment, electronics, appliances, medical devices, vehicles

framing.forConservatives: Property rights. If you bought it, you own it. You should be able to fix what you own.
framing.forProgressives: Environmental sustainability. Consumer protection against corporate control.
framing.forFarmers: Fix your own tractor. Don't wait three weeks for a dealer in planting season.

subPolicies.allies: Farmers' organizations, independent repair shops, consumer advocates, environmental groups, tech repair community
subPolicies.opposition: Major manufacturers (John Deere, Apple, medical device companies), authorized dealer networks

subPolicies.title: Civil Asset Forfeiture Reform
problem: Police can seize property (cash, cars, homes) without ever charging the owner with a crime
Property is 'guilty until proven innocent' — owner must prove it wasn't connected to crime
Law enforcement agencies often keep seized assets, creating profit incentive
Median cash seizure is ~$1,300 — not worth the legal fees to contest
Disproportionately affects low-income and minority communities
positions: Require criminal conviction before permanent forfeiture
Shift burden of proof to government
Redirect forfeiture proceeds to general fund (remove profit incentive)
Require clear and convincing evidence standard at minimum
Provide legal representation for those contesting seizures
Mandatory reporting of all seizures

framing.forConservatives: Property rights. Due process. Limited government. This is legalized theft.
framing.forProgressives: Racial justice. Economic justice. Police accountability.
framing.forEveryone: Your property shouldn't be guilty until you prove it innocent.

subPolicies.allies: Institute for Justice, ACLU, libertarian organizations, criminal justice reform groups
subPolicies.opposition: Law enforcement unions, prosecutors' associations, agencies that benefit from forfeiture funds

subPolicies.title: ESG & Stakeholder Capitalism Opposition
subPolicies.level: State (pension funds, state contracts), Federal (SEC rules)
problem: ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance) scores pressure companies to adopt specific political positions
Major asset managers (BlackRock, Vanguard, State Street) vote YOUR shares for ESG goals without your consent
Banks and insurers deny services based on ESG scores (energy companies, gun manufacturers, etc.)
Fiduciary duty to investors replaced with vague 'stakeholder' obligations
State pension funds forced into ESG investments that may underperform
positions: Fiduciary duty means financial returns: State pension funds must prioritize returns, not ESG goals
Pass-through voting: Asset managers must vote shares as beneficial owners direct, not as managers prefer
No ESG discrimination: Banks and insurers cannot deny services to legal industries based on ESG scores
Disclosure requirements: Companies must disclose ESG-related costs and impacts on returns
Anti-boycott provisions: State contracts cannot exclude companies for political stances

framing.forConservatives: Fiduciary duty. Shareholder rights. Stop politicizing retirement savings.
framing.forProgressives: Ask why billionaire asset managers get to vote your shares for their priorities, not yours.
framing.forEveryone: Your retirement savings should be managed for returns, not political agendas.

subPolicies.allies: State financial officers, energy sector, Second Amendment groups, free market think tanks
subPolicies.opposition: Major asset managers, ESG rating agencies, progressive advocacy groups

subPolicies.title: Healthcare Price Transparency
problem: Patients cannot get prices before receiving care
Same procedure varies 10x between facilities in same city
Insurance 'negotiated rates' are secret — you can't shop
Surprise bills from out-of-network providers
Hospital chargemasters are fiction — no one pays those rates
Existing federal transparency rules (2021) widely ignored, poorly enforced
positions: Enforce existing hospital price transparency rules with real penalties
Require binding upfront estimates for non-emergency care
All-payer claims databases at state level (every insurance payment public)
Real-time eligibility and price lookup tools
Ban gag clauses that prevent price disclosure
Reference pricing: Medicare pays market rate, not inflated hospital rate

framing.forConservatives: Free markets require price information. You can't have competition without prices.
framing.forProgressives: Patients deserve to know what they'll pay. End surprise bills.
framing.forEveryone: You wouldn't buy a car without knowing the price. Why accept that for surgery?

subPolicies.allies: Patient advocates, employers, some insurers, fiscal conservatives
subPolicies.opposition: Hospital systems, some provider groups that benefit from price opacity

subPolicies.title: Environmental Policy: Outcome-Based, State-Driven
problem: Environmental regulations increasingly driven by political agenda rather than measurable outcomes
One-size-fits-all federal mandates ignore regional differences
Permitting delays block infrastructure for years (average NEPA review: 4.5 years)
Regulations used as weapon against disfavored industries regardless of actual environmental impact
Compliance costs fall hardest on small businesses and rural communities
positions: Outcome-based standards: Set measurable environmental goals (air quality, water quality, species population), let states determine how to achieve them
Streamline permitting: Categorical exclusions for proven low-impact activities; concurrent (not sequential) reviews
Cost-benefit requirements: Rigorous analysis of costs vs. environmental benefits for all major rules
State primacy: States with proven track records should have primary implementation authority
Sunset provisions: Regulations expire unless renewed with demonstrated effectiveness

framing.forConservatives: Federalism. States know their environments better than Washington. Focus on results, not process.
framing.forProgressives: Outcome-based standards can achieve better environmental results faster than bureaucratic process.
framing.forEveryone: Clean air and water matter. Decade-long permitting delays don't help the environment.

subPolicies.allies: State environmental agencies, business groups, some conservation organizations focused on outcomes
subPolicies.opposition: National environmental groups invested in federal control, regulatory agencies protecting jurisdiction

policies.title: Food & Health Sovereignty
policies.description: Americans should have the freedom to make their own food and health choices, access products from local producers, and be protected from harmful substances that other developed nations have banned. Food freedom and medical freedom are fundamental rights.

subPolicies.title: Unpasteurized (Raw) Dairy Legalization
problem: Federal law prohibits interstate sale of raw milk
Many states ban or heavily restrict intrastate sales
Small dairy farmers cannot sell directly to willing consumers
Raw dairy consumed for millennia; many countries allow regulated sale
Enforcement includes armed raids on small farms
positions: Legalize on-farm sales (consumer can inspect conditions)
Legalize retail sales with appropriate labeling and consumer acknowledgment
Allow herd-share arrangements (consumer owns portion of animal)
Reasonable food safety testing without prohibitive costs
Repeal federal ban on interstate raw milk sales
Allow states to determine their own raw dairy policies
End FDA enforcement actions against small producers selling to informed consumers

framing.forEveryone: Adults should be free to buy raw milk if they understand the risks. This is about freedom and informed choice.

subPolicies.currentStatus: Legal for retail sale: ~13 states | On-farm sales only: ~17 states | Herd-shares only: ~10 states | Illegal: ~10 states
subPolicies.allies: Farm-to-Consumer Legal Defense Fund, Weston A. Price Foundation, libertarian groups
subPolicies.opposition: Industrial dairy, some public health officials

subPolicies.title: Local Food & Cottage Food Reform
problem: Cottage food laws (home-based food businesses) vary widely and are often restrictive
Small farmers face same regulatory burden as large operations
Direct-to-consumer sales restricted by rules designed for wholesale distribution
On-farm processing facilities subject to industrial-scale requirements
Small meat processors nearly eliminated by USDA inspection requirements
positions: Expand list of allowed cottage food products
Increase or eliminate sales caps
Allow online and delivery sales, not just farmers markets
Clear labeling requirements instead of outright bans
Exempt direct farm-to-consumer sales from regulations designed for wholesale
Allow on-farm poultry processing up to reasonable limits (1,000-20,000 birds/year)
Support custom-exempt meat processing for farm-direct sales
Producer-only farmers markets with streamlined requirements
Support for small-scale USDA-inspected processing facilities
Mobile slaughter units for rural areas
Shared-use commercial kitchens for cottage food producers

framing.forEveryone: A grandmother shouldn't need a $50,000 commercial kitchen to sell cookies. Let people cook.

subPolicies.modelLegislation: Wyoming, Maine, and Utah have passed Food Freedom Acts that allow direct producer-to-consumer sales with informed consent, exempt from licensing and inspection requirements.
subPolicies.allies: Farm bureaus, local food movements, homesteading communities
subPolicies.opposition: Industrial food processors, some health departments

subPolicies.title: Removing Toxic Chemicals from Food Supply
subPolicies.level: Federal (FDA regulatory action or congressional legislation)
problem: Red Dye No. 3 — banned in cosmetics since 1990 but still in food; linked to cancer
Red Dye No. 40 — linked to hyperactivity; requires warning labels in EU
Yellow No. 5 & 6 — require warnings in EU; linked to behavioral issues
Brominated vegetable oil (BVO) — banned in EU and Japan; neurological concerns
Potassium bromate — banned in EU, UK, Canada, Brazil; classified as possible carcinogen
Azodicarbonamide — banned in EU and Australia; used in US bread products
BHA/BHT preservatives — restricted in many countries; potential carcinogens
rBGH/rBST (bovine growth hormone) — banned in EU, Canada, Australia; linked to health concerns
positions: Immediate ban on Red Dye No. 3 (already banned in cosmetics — extend to food)
Immediate ban on Brominated vegetable oil
Immediate ban on Potassium bromate
EU-style warning labels for artificial dyes linked to behavioral issues
Clear disclosure of all artificial additives
Country of origin labeling expansion
Review all GRAS (Generally Recognized as Safe) substances grandfathered from old regulations
End industry self-certification for new food additives
Adopt precautionary principle — burden of proof on manufacturer
Harmonize with EU/international standards where appropriate

framing.forParents: Protect children from additives linked to behavioral and health problems.
framing.forConsumers: Americans deserve the same protections as Europeans.
framing.forConservatives: Informed consent — let people know what's in their food.

subPolicies.allies: Consumer advocacy groups, parents' organizations, reformulating food companies
subPolicies.opposition: Food industry associations, chemical manufacturers

subPolicies.title: Medical Freedom & Informed Consent
problem: Medical mandates override individual autonomy
Vaccine requirements for employment and education expanding
Limited informed consent in emergency situations
Alternative treatments suppressed or banned
One-size-fits-all mandates ignore individual health conditions
positions: Individuals have the right to make their own medical decisions
Informed consent requires full disclosure of risks, benefits, and alternatives
Government mandates should be limited and subject to robust exemption rights
Medical decisions should remain between patient and provider
Access to treatments should not be contingent on accepting other treatments
Require meaningful informed consent for all medical interventions
Protect religious, philosophical, and medical exemptions to mandates
Prohibit termination based solely on medical treatment decisions
No medical requirements for public education beyond genuine public health necessities
Protect healthcare providers who conscientiously object to procedures
Right to try experimental treatments with informed consent
Strengthen medical privacy protections; limit employer/government access to records

framing.forEveryone: Your body, your choice. Medical freedom is fundamental—not negotiable.

subPolicies.allies: Medical freedom organizations, religious groups, civil liberties advocates
subPolicies.opposition: Public health establishment, some medical associations

policies.title: Property Rights
policies.description: Property rights are foundational to liberty. Government and private entities increasingly infringe on what Americans can do with their own property. When you buy something, you should own it — fully.

subPolicies.title: Homeowners Association Reform
problem: Mandatory membership with no opt-out option for existing communities
Broad, vague restrictions enforced arbitrarily
Fines and penalties with limited due process
Foreclosure authority for unpaid assessments (including minor amounts)
Selective enforcement based on board member relationships
Limited transparency in financial management
Elections subject to manipulation by management companies
Restrictions that conflict with state/federal law (solar panels, flags, etc.)
positions: Require open meetings and access to financial records
Mandate competitive bidding for contracts
Prohibit board members from self-dealing
Require independent audits for HOAs above certain size
Term limits for board members
Cap fines; require escalating warnings before penalties
Prohibit foreclosure for fines (assessments only, with limits)
Require due process before any penalty (notice, hearing, appeal)
Statute of limitations on violations
Selective enforcement as affirmative defense
Protect solar panels and energy equipment
Protect flag display (US flag already protected; extend to state/military)
Allow political signs (time-limited during elections)
Allow vegetable gardens (reasonable backyard use)
Strengthen disability accommodations enforcement
Protect reasonable religious expression
Mandatory disclosure to buyers before purchase
CC&R plain language requirements
Online access to all governing documents

framing.forConservatives: Property rights — you bought it, you should be able to use it.
framing.forHomeowners: Protection from petty tyranny and arbitrary enforcement.
framing.forEveryone: HOAs exercise government-like power without government-like accountability.

subPolicies.allies: Property rights groups, homeowner advocates, real estate consumer groups
subPolicies.opposition: HOA management companies, some HOA boards

subPolicies.title: Eminent Domain Reform
subPolicies.level: State (many reformed after Kelo; some need strengthening)
problem: Since Kelo v. City of New London (2005), 'public use' stretched to allow takings for private development
Property can be taken and given to private developers if it might increase tax revenue
Low-income neighborhoods targeted for 'redevelopment'
Compensation often inadequate (fair market value may not cover relocation costs)
Threat of eminent domain used to coerce below-market sales
positions: Public Use Restriction: Limit eminent domain to true public use (roads, utilities, public buildings)
No Private-to-Private Transfers: Prohibit taking property to give to another private party
Just Compensation Plus: Compensation must include relocation costs, not just market value
Blight Definition: Tighten definition of 'blight' to prevent abuse
Right of First Refusal: If taken property not used for stated purpose, original owner can repurchase

framing.forEveryone: Your home isn't a revenue opportunity for developers. Eminent domain should be rare and compensated fairly.

subPolicies.allies: Property rights groups, Castle Coalition, affected communities
subPolicies.opposition: Developers, municipal governments, economic development agencies

subPolicies.title: Mineral Rights Protection
problem: Mineral rights severed from surface rights on vast majority of American land
Most property buyers have no opportunity to purchase mineral rights — already owned by corporations
Corporations sit on mineral rights indefinitely without productive use — 'mineral right squatting'
Similar market failure to patent trolls and domain name squatters
Landowners have limited rights when mineral owners access their property
Foreign corporations increasingly own American mineral rights
Concentrated ownership enables market manipulation and speculation
positions: Active Development Requirement: Mineral rights must show active exploration, development, or production within defined period (e.g., 10 years)
Holding Fees: Escalating annual fees for undeveloped mineral rights — discourages pure speculation
Reversion to Surface Owner: Abandoned or long-inactive mineral rights revert to surface property owner
Bona Fide Development Standard: Token drilling/exploration doesn't satisfy requirement — must be genuine commercial activity
Exemption for Active Leases: Rights under active lease with producing operator are protected
Access Compensation: Fair compensation for surface disruption, not just mineral value
Restoration Bonds: Mineral operators must post bonds for full site restoration
Notice Requirements: Advance notice and negotiation before surface access
Damage Liability: Strict liability for surface damage, groundwater contamination
Right of First Refusal: Surface owners have first right to purchase mineral rights when sold
Reunification Incentives: Tax incentives for reunifying mineral and surface rights
Disclosure Requirements: Clear disclosure of severed mineral rights in all property transactions
Anti-Concentration Limits: Prevent single entities from controlling dominant share of regional mineral rights
Foreign Ownership Restrictions: Limit or prohibit foreign ownership of mineral rights (national security)
Transparency Registry: Public registry of all mineral rights ownership
Shell Company Disclosure: Require disclosure of beneficial owners behind corporate mineral owners

framing.forConservatives: Property rights — if you own the land, you should have opportunity to own what's under it. End corporate squatting.
framing.forProgressives: Environmental protection through landowner empowerment. End extractive industry exploitation.
framing.forRuralCommunities: Give families control over their land. Stop absentee corporations from dictating land use.
framing.forEnergyIndependence: Active development requirements increase domestic production; speculation decreases it.

subPolicies.note: This policy must carefully balance protecting current property rights (mineral owners have legitimate ownership) with preventing market failures. Focus on use requirements and access reforms rather than confiscation. Model on successful 'use it or lose it' precedents in water rights, spectrum allocation, and mining claims.
subPolicies.allies: Farm bureaus, rural landowners, environmental groups, energy independence advocates
subPolicies.opposition: Oil/gas companies, mineral speculators, some property rights absolutists

policies.title: Government Accountability & Reform
policies.description: Americans have lost trust in government institutions. Restoring accountability requires structural reforms that limit conflicts of interest, increase transparency, and return power to citizens. Those who govern should be accountable to those they govern.

subPolicies.title: Congressional Stock Trading Ban
problem: Members of Congress trade stocks while having access to non-public information
Exposed trades during COVID-19 pandemic (insider information on economic impact)
Committee members trading stocks of companies they regulate
Defense committee members investing in defense contractors
STOCK Act (2012) has proven inadequate — weak enforcement, minor penalties
positions: Full Trading Ban: Prohibit members and senior staff from trading individual stocks
Blind Trusts or Index Funds Only: Investments limited to diversified holdings without individual stock selection
Family Coverage: Extend restrictions to spouse and dependent children
Meaningful Penalties: Substantial fines (percentage of trade value), referral for prosecution
Disclosure Enhancement: Real-time disclosure of all trades (current law allows 45 days)
Independent Enforcement: Remove enforcement from congressional self-policing

framing.forEveryone: If you serve in Congress, you shouldn't get rich trading on inside information. Ban it completely.

subPolicies.momentum: Bipartisan support exists — bills introduced by both parties. Multiple competing proposals (strongest: full ban; weakest: enhanced disclosure). Public support exceeds 70% across party lines. Several members have voluntarily divested.
subPolicies.allies: Good government groups, both progressive and conservative reformers
subPolicies.opposition: Many current members benefit from status quo

subPolicies.title: Term Limits
problem: Career politicians become detached from constituents and beholden to permanent Washington
Average House tenure has increased dramatically over past century
Incumbent re-election rates exceed 90%
Seniority system concentrates power among longest-serving members
Permanent political class with different interests than constituents
positions: House of Representatives: 6 terms (12 years)
Senate: 2 terms (12 years)
Combined congressional service: 12-18 years total
Governor: 2 terms (already exists in most states)
State legislators: 8-12 years
Implementation via constitutional amendment (traditional path — requires 2/3 Congress + 3/4 states)
Article V Convention of States (34 states call convention; 38 ratify)
State-level first: term limits for state legislators build momentum

framing.forEveryone: Public service shouldn't be a lifetime career. Term limits would break the stranglehold of career politicians.

subPolicies.viabilityNote: Federal: LOW (requires constitutional amendment) | State: HIGH (15 states have legislative term limits)
subPolicies.allies: U.S. Term Limits, Convention of States, grassroots movements
subPolicies.opposition: Incumbent politicians, congressional leadership

subPolicies.title: End Lobbying: The Citizen Voice Portal
subPolicies.level: Federal (constitutional amendment may be required for full implementation)
problem: Billions spent annually by corporations and special interests to influence legislation
Politicians claim they need lobbyists to understand issues — this is a solvable information problem
Rich entities hidden behind layers of PACs and organizations buy laws that hurt ordinary citizens
Technical expertise can come from public experts, academics, GAO — not paid advocates
Reform attempts get worked around; the only solution is replacement
Every citizen should have equal voice — not voice proportional to wealth
positions: Equal Voice: Every citizen gets 100 points annually — billionaire and minimum wage worker identical
Policy Positions: Allocate points to specific policy positions you support
Flexible Allocation: Put all 100 on one issue you care deeply about, or spread across many
Annual Cycle: Fresh allocation each year; priorities can shift
Three-Round Refinement: Citizens submit positions, top tier advances through rounds, final ranking determined
Top 3 Positions BINDING: Congress MUST introduce legislation and hold floor vote
Ban Paid Lobbying: No more professional lobbyists paid to influence legislation
Citizens Can Still Petition: First Amendment right preserved — individuals can contact representatives
Expert Testimony Preserved: Public expert panels, academic testimony, GAO analysis — not paid advocates
Revolving Door Closed: Lifetime ban on former officials becoming lobbyists
One Citizen One Voice: Tied to government credentials, encrypted and anonymized
Open Source Code: Everyone can see exactly how it works; no black boxes

framing.forPopulistRight: End the swamp. No more corporations buying laws. Your voice equals George Soros's voice.
framing.forPopulistLeft: End corporate capture. No more billionaires writing legislation. Democracy for actual people.
framing.forEveryone: Why should a hedge fund have more influence over YOUR government than you do? One citizen, one voice.

subPolicies.implementationChallenges: Constitutional questions on banning paid lobbying; $4+ billion lobbying industry will fight; many politicians benefit from status quo; digital divide requires non-digital access options
subPolicies.allies: Populists left and right, anti-corruption advocates, democracy reform movements, ordinary citizens
subPolicies.opposition: Lobbying industry, corporations with legislative agendas, politicians benefiting from status quo

subPolicies.title: Regulatory State Reform
problem: Unelected bureaucracies make rules with the force of law, violating separation of powers
Agencies issue thousands of rules annually; Congress passes hundreds of laws
Chevron deference allows agencies to interpret their own authority broadly
Cost of federal regulations estimated at $2+ trillion annually
Administrative law judges within agencies judge their own cases
positions: REINS Act: Major rules (>$100M impact) require congressional approval
End Chevron Deference: Courts should not defer to agency interpretation of ambiguous statutes
Regulatory Budget: Cap total regulatory costs; new rules require offsetting eliminations
Sunset Provisions: Regulations automatically expire unless reauthorized
Independent ALJs: Remove administrative law judges from agency control
Cost-Benefit Requirements: Rigorous, independent cost-benefit analysis for all rules

framing.forEveryone: Agencies should execute the law—not write it. Congress must reclaim its authority.

subPolicies.allies: Business groups, libertarian organizations, constitutional scholars
subPolicies.opposition: Agencies, regulatory beneficiaries, administrative law establishment

subPolicies.title: Legislative Reform: Transparency, Sunset & Accountability
problem: Thousand-page bills passed with hours or minutes to review
Unrelated provisions attached to must-pass legislation
Laws remain on books indefinitely — never reviewed for effectiveness
Complex issues used to justify omnibus bills that escape scrutiny
Members vote on bills they haven't read
Lobbyists insert provisions that would fail as standalone bills
positions: Single Subject Rule: Each bill addresses one subject (many state constitutions have this)
Title-Content Consistency: Bill contents must match the title/stated purpose
Minimum Review Period: No vote until bill text available for 72 hours minimum
Read the Bills Act: Require attestation that member (or senior staff) has read the bill
Separate Votes: Amendments voted separately from underlying bill
Plain Language Summaries: Non-lawyer readable summary required for every bill
Default Expiration: All non-constitutional laws expire automatically after set period
Tiered Renewal: Routine laws 5 years, major policy 10 years, foundational 20 years
Effectiveness Review: Before renewal, require assessment of whether law achieved purpose
Complex Issue Handling: Reform packages broken into separate single-subject bills with sequenced voting
Phase Gates: Complex reforms implemented in phases with review gates and abort mechanisms

framing.forConservatives: Government must continuously justify its power. Bad laws die automatically.
framing.forProgressives: Regular review ensures laws adapt to changing conditions and actually work.
framing.forEveryone: No more thousand-page bills no one reads. Complexity handled transparently, not hidden.

subPolicies.allies: Good government groups, transparency advocates, libertarians, fiscal conservatives
subPolicies.opposition: Legislative leadership (both parties), lobbyists who benefit from complexity

subPolicies.title: Emergency Powers Reform
problem: COVID-19 revealed governors wielding near-unlimited emergency powers for years
Emergency declarations extended indefinitely without legislative review
Businesses destroyed by executive order without due process or compensation
Churches closed while liquor stores stayed open — arbitrary enforcement
Constitutional rights suspended by executive fiat
No mechanism for citizens to challenge emergency measures in real-time
Emergency powers designed for hurricanes used for indefinite social control
positions: Automatic Expiration: Emergency declarations expire after 30-60 days without legislative renewal
Legislative Approval Required: Any extension beyond initial period requires affirmative legislative vote
No Successive Declarations: Cannot declare new emergency for same event to circumvent time limits
Termination Authority: Legislature can terminate emergency by majority vote at any time
Enumerated Powers: Define specific powers available during emergency — no open-ended authority
Constitutional Carve-Outs: Certain rights cannot be suspended even during emergency (worship, assembly, speech)
Business Closure Standards: Clear criteria for which businesses can be closed and under what conditions
Geographic Limits: Emergency powers limited to affected areas, not statewide when localized
Compensation for Closures: Businesses closed by government order entitled to compensation
Expedited Judicial Review: Fast-track court review of emergency measures
Personal Liability: Officials who exceed emergency authority face personal liability

framing.forConservatives: Separation of powers. Executive cannot rule by decree indefinitely.
framing.forProgressives: Protect civil liberties. Prevent future administrations from abusing emergency powers.
framing.forBusinessOwners: Never again will your livelihood be destroyed by indefinite executive order.
framing.forEveryone: Emergencies don't suspend the Constitution. Temporary means temporary.

subPolicies.provenSuccess: Post-COVID, numerous states have passed emergency powers reform: Ohio, Kansas, Pennsylvania, Kentucky, and others. This is a winning issue with demonstrated bipartisan support.
subPolicies.allies: Libertarians, civil liberties groups, business associations, constitutional scholars
subPolicies.opposition: Governors (both parties), public health establishment

policies.title: Election Integrity
policies.description: Free and fair elections are essential to self-governance. Reforms should make it easy to vote and hard to cheat, while restoring public confidence in electoral outcomes. Every legal vote should count; no illegal vote should count.

subPolicies.title: Voter Identification
problem: Many states allow voting without verifying identity
Inconsistent standards create confusion across jurisdictions
Lack of verification undermines confidence in results
Absentee ballot verification often weaker than in-person
positions: Require government-issued photo ID to vote in person
Free ID available to any citizen who lacks one
Provisional ballot available for those without ID (with verification process)
ID requirement for requesting and returning absentee ballots
Accept multiple forms (driver's license, passport, military ID, state ID)
Reasonable accommodations for elderly and disabled

framing.forEveryone: You need an ID to buy beer—why not to vote? Free ID plus voter ID requirement is common sense.

subPolicies.currentStatus: Majority of states have some form of voter ID; broad public support across party lines
subPolicies.allies: Election integrity advocates, most state legislators
subPolicies.opposition: Some voting rights groups concerned about access barriers

subPolicies.title: Paper Ballots
problem: Electronic-only voting machines have no audit trail
Voting systems vulnerable to hacking and malfunction
Internet-connected systems create security vulnerabilities
Difficult to verify accuracy or conduct meaningful recounts without paper
positions: Hand-marked paper ballots as primary voting method
Where machines are used, voter-verified paper audit trail required
Paper ballots preserved for recount and audit purposes
No internet-connected voting systems
Voter verifies paper ballot before casting
Paper is the official record for recounts

framing.forEveryone: Paper ballots are simple, transparent, and trustworthy. High-tech isn't always better.

subPolicies.currentStatus: Most states already use paper ballots; consensus building across political spectrum
subPolicies.allies: Election security experts, both parties increasingly
subPolicies.opposition: Some election equipment vendors

subPolicies.title: Chain of Custody & Security
problem: Ballots transported without clear tracking documentation
Unsecured or unmonitored drop boxes in some jurisdictions
Gaps in custody records make irregularities difficult to trace
Insufficient observer access at critical stages
positions: Documented chain of custody for all ballots from printing to counting
Bipartisan observer access at all stages of election process
Video surveillance of ballot storage and counting areas
Secure ballot transport with multiple witnesses
Secured, monitored drop boxes (if used at all)
Real-time tracking and documentation systems
Criminal penalties for chain-of-custody violations

framing.forEveryone: We track Amazon packages—why not ballots? Tight security builds trust.

subPolicies.allies: Election integrity advocates, law enforcement
subPolicies.opposition: Some election administrators concerned about implementation costs

subPolicies.title: Timely Results & Audits
problem: Days or weeks to count votes in some jurisdictions
Delayed results erode public confidence
Inconsistent and rare audits across states
Some states prohibit early processing of mail ballots
positions: Count all ballots election night to extent possible
Early processing of mail ballots (where permitted) to enable timely counting
Mandatory post-election audits (risk-limiting audits preferred)
Random precinct hand-count verification
Full audit if margin within specified threshold
Results announced same night or within 24 hours
Public observation of counting process

framing.forEveryone: France counts 40 million votes in 24 hours. America can do better.

probationaryPeriod: No Public Benefits: Zero access to welfare, food stamps, housing assistance, Medicaid
Full Tax Obligation: Pay all taxes from day one — same as citizens
Self-Sufficiency Required: Must maintain housing and employment
Criminal Accountability: Any conviction for non-trivial offense = immediate deportation
No Chain Migration: Cannot sponsor relatives during probationary period
afterProbation: Full Resident Status: Eligible for permanent residency
Benefit Eligibility: Access to social safety net (having contributed for 2 years)
Path to Citizenship: Standard naturalization process available
Family Sponsorship: May sponsor immediate family (who also enter probationary status)

framing.forConservatives: Rule of law restored. No more illegal immigration. No free ride. Immigrants must prove themselves.
framing.forProgressives: Genuinely open borders for anyone willing to work. No discrimination by country. Humane, legal pathway.
framing.forLibertarians: Free movement of labor. Minimal government barriers. Self-selection of productive individuals.
framing.forEveryone: We get immigrants who WANT to contribute and prove it through action, not paperwork.

challenges: Mass removal: Logistically complex, emotionally difficult, legally contested
Defining 'contribution': Who decides? What standards? Bureaucratic discretion concerns
Enforcement gaps: Probationary violations require robust tracking and enforcement
Political will: Neither party fully embraces this — too open for right, too accountable for left
subPolicies.allies: Rule-of-law conservatives, libertarians, legal immigrants, working-class Americans
subPolicies.opposition: Open-borders absolutists, amnesty advocates, some business interests (want cheap exploitable labor)

subPolicies.title: Dual Citizenship in Government
subPolicies.framingNote: This is NOT about ethnicity, religion, or national origin. This is about formal legal obligations to foreign governments that create potential conflicts of interest. A naturalized citizen who has renounced prior citizenship has no such conflict.
problem: Dual citizens may owe military service, taxes, or other obligations to foreign governments
Security clearance standards already consider foreign ties
Elected officials and senior appointees make decisions affecting foreign nations
Appearance of divided loyalty undermines public trust
positions: Elected Officials: Federal elected officials should not hold citizenship of any foreign nation
Senior Appointees: Cabinet members and senior officials should renounce foreign citizenship
Security Positions: Apply existing security clearance standards consistently
Disclosure: At minimum, require disclosure of any foreign citizenships
Judicial Nominees: Federal judges should not hold foreign citizenship
implementationChallenges: Constitutional questions: Can citizenship requirements be added to elected office?
Political sensitivity: Will be mischaracterized regardless of framing
Enforcement: Some countries don't recognize renunciation
Scope: How far down the government hierarchy?

framing.forConservatives: American officials should have undivided loyalty to America.
framing.forProgressives: Transparency and accountability in government — know who your leaders serve.
framing.forEveryone: Those who make decisions for America should be accountable only to America.

subPolicies.allies: National security hawks, sovereignty advocates
subPolicies.opposition: Civil liberties groups (framing concerns), affected communities

subPolicies.title: War & Military Intervention: Defense Only
subPolicies.corePrinciple: No War Unless American Lives Are At Risk. War means killing people — including inevitable innocent bystanders. This requires justification beyond 'interests.' No nation-state has attacked American soil since Pearl Harbor. Our recent wars have been choices, not necessities. Economic reasons are not sufficient justification to kill people.
problem: Forever wars with no clear exit strategy or measurable victory conditions
Congress has abdicated war-making authority to the executive branch
Military-industrial complex profits from endless conflict
American blood and treasure spent on other nations' conflicts
Last attack on US soil by nation-state: Pearl Harbor (1941)
noWarPositions: No war in the Middle East — Not our conflict; not worth American lives
No war with China — Competition yes, war no
No war with Russia — Not our border, not our war
No war with Iran — Containment and deterrence, not invasion
No war with North Korea — Deterrence works
No war with Venezuela — Not a threat to American lives
No 'humanitarian' interventions — Our military exists to protect Americans, not remake the world
No regime change operations — History shows these fail catastrophically
whenWarIsJustified: Attack on American soil: Direct attack on US territory triggers full defensive response
Attack on Americans: Large-scale attack killing American citizens (e.g., 9/11-scale terrorism)
Imminent verified threat: Confirmed imminent attack on American soil — not speculative 'WMD' claims
Defense of territories: Attack on US territories, possessions, or military installations
notJustifiedFor: Economic interests: Oil, trade routes, resources — not worth killing for
Spreading democracy: Not our job; doesn't work anyway
Humanitarian concerns: Tragic, but not a military mission
Protecting 'interests' abroad: Vague 'interests' have justified every failed war
Honoring alliance commitments: Alliances should be defensive, not offensive
Maintaining 'credibility': Credibility doesn't require endless war
Preemption based on speculation: 'They might attack someday' is not justification
defenseInvestment: Mainland Defense: Anti-missile systems, air defense, coastal defense — make attacking US soil impossible
Satellite Locations: Defend territories (Guam, Puerto Rico, etc.) with serious defensive capability
Cyber Defense: Protect critical infrastructure from cyber attack
Border Security: Actual security, not just enforcement theater
Nuclear Deterrent: Maintain credible second-strike capability
Domestic Manufacturing: Defense industrial base should not depend on foreign supply chains
protectingAmericansAbroad: Consular Services: Robust embassy/consular support for Americans in trouble
Evacuation Capability: Ability to extract Americans from dangerous situations
Legal Assistance: Help Americans navigate foreign legal systems
Diplomatic Pressure: Use diplomatic channels to protect American citizens
Hostage Recovery: Negotiation, intelligence, targeted operations — not invasion
NOT War: An American getting in trouble abroad does not justify invading countries
allianceReform: Defensive Only: US alliances should be defensive — we defend allies if attacked, not if they start wars
Burden Sharing: Allies must contribute meaningfully to their own defense
No Tripwire Forces: Don't station troops where their death automatically triggers war
Congressional Approval: No president can commit US to war without Congress
Treaty Review: Review all defense commitments — which still serve American interests?
Withdrawal Timelines: Phase out forward deployments that serve allies more than America
taiwanPosition: Taiwan is NOT American soil. Taiwanese are not American citizens.
Strategic Reality: Current interest is semiconductor supply chain, not Taiwan itself
Solution: Broker a 20-year transition deal with China
During 20 Years: Build complete domestic chip manufacturing capability
After 20 Years: Exit Taiwan in totality. The fate of Taiwan is between China and the Taiwanese.
Principle: We don't fight wars over other people's territory. We solve our strategic vulnerabilities through investment, not blood.

framing.forConservatives: Put America first. Stop spending American blood and treasure on other people's wars. Rebuild military for defense, not empire.
framing.forProgressives: End the forever wars. Stop killing innocent civilians abroad. Invest in America instead of bombs.
framing.forVeterans: Your lives are too valuable to waste on wars of choice. We should only send you to fight when America is actually threatened.
framing.forEveryone: War means killing people, including innocent bystanders. That requires real justification. 'Interests' isn't enough.

subPolicies.historicalRecord: Last attack on US soil: Pearl Harbor (1941) — nation-state attack; 9/11 (2001) — non-state actors. Recent wars: Iraq, Afghanistan, Libya, Syria involvement — all choices, not defensive necessities. Results: Trillions spent, thousands of American lives lost, hundreds of thousands of foreign civilians killed, regions destabilized.
subPolicies.allies: Non-interventionist conservatives, anti-war progressives, libertarians, veterans groups (some), fiscal conservatives
subPolicies.opposition: Military-industrial complex, neoconservatives, foreign policy establishment, defense contractors

policies.title: Healthcare System Reform
policies.description: Healthcare markets should not be consolidated to a few large players. No government policy should enrich a subset of companies in an industry. If a function that generates significant revenue is unavoidable to properly regulate, it must be an open and competitive process. Government can't pick winners. Marketplaces provide the best results.

subPolicies.title: Competitive Healthcare Markets
problem: Hospital systems consolidated into regional monopolies
PBMs (pharmacy benefit managers) control drug pricing with no transparency
Certificate of Need laws prevent new hospitals from opening
Regulatory capture protects incumbents from competition
Prices obscured — patients can't shop for value
Government programs pick winners, enriching connected companies
positions: Certificate of Need Repeal: Eliminate laws requiring government permission to open healthcare facilities
Price Transparency: All healthcare providers must publish prices upfront (builds on existing federal requirements)
PBM Transparency: Require disclosure of rebates, spreads, and pricing arrangements
Anti-Consolidation: Strengthen antitrust enforcement in healthcare mergers
Competitive Bidding: Any government healthcare spending must use competitive bidding — no sole-source contracts
Cash Pay Options: Providers must offer cash prices; payments in any currency accepted
emergencyCare: Emergency care is a business — businesses compete
If costs aren't obscured and payments are made in cash (any currency), working emergency systems are achievable
Rural areas can have single facilities; if rates rise too high, competition is enabled
No special exemptions for emergency care from price transparency requirements

framing.corePrinciple: Government can't pick winners to enrich. Every company should compete on equal footing.
framing.forConservatives: End crony capitalism in healthcare. Let markets work.
framing.forProgressives: Break up healthcare monopolies that gouge patients.
framing.forEveryone: You deserve to know prices before treatment, not after.

subPolicies.allies: Direct primary care, patient advocates, small practices, fiscal conservatives
subPolicies.opposition: Hospital systems, PBMs, entrenched healthcare corporations

subPolicies.title: Insurance Market Reform
problem: Insurance tied to employment — distorts market, locks workers into jobs
Can't buy insurance across state lines or from unconventional sources
Complex regulations benefit large insurers, crush small entrants
Pre-existing conditions create coverage gaps
Mandates and regulations make policies expensive
retailInsuranceSales: Anywhere Sales: Insurance should be purchasable like any other good — at Costco, Walmart, online, or your neighborhood shop
Operational Standards: Any seller must meet operational standards, but no artificial barriers to entry
Affiliation Benefits: Your affiliations can get you access to different insurance options, but shouldn't be required
Interstate Purchase: Buy insurance from any state that allows it
preExistingConditions: Cannot Deny Coverage: Insurance companies cannot deny coverage to anyone
Age-Banded Pricing: Policies priced by age band — younger people pay less (actuarially justified)
Continuous Coverage Rule: 6-month grace period — if your last policy was within 6 months (and prior coverage exceeded 12 months), you stay in normal age-band pricing
Lapse Penalty: If coverage lapses >6 months, can be assessed for prior conditions and placed at high end of age band
Rate Cap: Cannot charge more than 20× average rate OR 40× lowest rate (whichever is lower)
subPolicies.designRationale: This system prevents the adverse selection death spiral (where only sick people buy insurance) while avoiding mandates. Continuous coverage incentivizes staying insured. Age-banding keeps premiums affordable for young people. Rate caps ensure no one is priced out entirely.
positions: Allow retail insurance sales from any qualified seller
Enable interstate insurance purchases
Protect pre-existing conditions with continuous coverage incentives
Use age-banded pricing instead of community rating
Cap rates to prevent pricing out the sick

framing.forConservatives: Free market insurance without mandates. Personal responsibility rewarded.
framing.forProgressives: No one denied coverage. Rate caps protect the sick.
framing.forEveryone: Buy insurance anywhere, keep it when you change jobs, and know you can't be priced out.

subPolicies.allies: Health sharing ministries, direct primary care, free market healthcare advocates
subPolicies.opposition: Large insurers, healthcare establishment, ACA defenders

subPolicies.title: Medicare & Medicaid: Phase-Out
problem: Government programs ARE government picking winners
Medicare prices distort entire healthcare market
Medicaid creates dependency and crowds out private alternatives
Fraud, waste, and abuse endemic to both programs
Unfunded liabilities threaten fiscal sustainability
positions: Phase-Out, Not Elimination: Programs phased out over time — not immediate deprecation
Protect Current Beneficiaries: Those currently dependent on programs protected during transition
Tied to Alternative System Maturity: Phase-out timeline contingent on proof that alternative market-based system is working
Beneficial Change Requirement: Must demonstrate beneficial change before each phase-out step
No Cliff: Gradual transition with off-ramps if problems emerge
subPolicies.strategicReality: This is a generational project, not a near-term campaign. Medicare is politically popular and seniors vote. Focus on (1) competitive alternatives that demonstrate market healthcare can work, (2) transparency reforms that expose program waste, (3) building public understanding of fiscal unsustainability. Immediate 'abolish Medicare' campaigns are political suicide.

framing.forConservatives: End government distortion of healthcare markets. Let competition work.
framing.forProgressives: The current system enriches corporations. A competitive system could serve patients better.
framing.forEveryone: We need sustainable healthcare, not programs heading toward bankruptcy.

subPolicies.allies: Fiscal conservatives, free market think tanks, some libertarians
subPolicies.opposition: AARP, healthcare industry (major revenue source), seniors, progressives

policies.title: Education Reform
policies.description: Education belongs to families and communities, not federal bureaucrats. You should not be forced to attend any school. The Department of Education should be at the state level. Curriculums are determined by the state and municipality, with those freedoms guaranteed by the federal level.

subPolicies.title: School Choice & Vouchers
problem: Children assigned to schools based on zip code
Families with means can move or pay for private school; others are trapped
Public school monopoly has no competitive pressure to improve
One-size-fits-all approach fails diverse student needs
Teacher unions prioritize adult interests over student outcomes
positions: Universal Vouchers: Every student receives voucher worth current per-pupil spending
Portable Funding: Money follows the student to any school they choose
State Schools: Any school that meets state standards and accepts vouchers qualifies as 'state school'
Curriculum Freedom: Schools can teach anything — but only get vouchers if they meet state standards
Special Needs: Higher voucher amount for special needs students — let the market create specialized schools
No Forced Attendance: Families choose; no child forced to attend any particular school
standardsAccountability: State Standards: Each state sets its own curriculum standards for voucher eligibility
Municipal Flexibility: Municipalities can add requirements within state framework
Federal Role: Guarantee the freedom of states and localities to set standards — no federal curriculum
Transparency: All schools receiving vouchers must publish outcomes data

framing.forConservatives: Parents, not bureaucrats, decide where children learn.
framing.forProgressives: Low-income families deserve the same choices wealthy families have.
framing.forEveryone: Competition improves quality. Let schools compete for students.

subPolicies.allies: School choice organizations, parental rights groups, many conservatives, urban education reformers
subPolicies.opposition: Teacher unions, public school establishment, some progressives

subPolicies.title: Eliminate Federal Department of Education
problem: Federal involvement in education began in 1979 — outcomes have not improved
Federal mandates impose one-size-fits-all requirements on diverse states
Money flows to Washington, bureaucracy takes its cut, remainder returns with strings attached
No constitutional authority for federal education involvement
Removes education decisions from parents and communities
positions: Abolish Federal DoE: Return all education authority to states
Block Grant Transition: If federal money continues, block grants with no strings attached
State DoE: Education departments operate at state level where they belong
Federal Role Limited To: Protecting state/local freedoms, civil rights enforcement, data collection (optional)
subPolicies.historicalContext: The federal Department of Education was created in 1979. U.S. educational outcomes have not improved relative to other developed nations since its creation. Federal spending has increased dramatically while results have stagnated. The experiment has failed.

framing.forConservatives: Restore constitutional order. Education is a state and local matter.
framing.forProgressives: Stop sending money to Washington bureaucracy. Keep it in communities.
framing.forEveryone: Forty-five years of federal involvement haven't improved outcomes. Try something different.

subPolicies.allies: State sovereignty advocates, fiscal conservatives, many Republicans
subPolicies.opposition: Education establishment, teacher unions, federal bureaucracy

subPolicies.title: Higher Education Reform
problem: Federal student loans have inflated tuition massively
$1.7+ trillion in student debt, much of it for low-value degrees
Universities captured unlimited government-backed money flow
Administrative bloat funded by easy credit
Students take on debt without understanding ROI
positions: End Federal Guarantees: Government should not fund or guarantee higher education loans
K-12 First: Government must make primary and secondary education work properly before getting involved in higher ed
Skin in the Game: If loans continue, universities should share default risk
Outcome Disclosure: Require schools to disclose graduate employment and earnings data by major
Alternative Pathways: Support vocational training, apprenticeships, and non-degree credentials

framing.corePrinciple: Fix K-12 first. A broken foundation can't support a good system above it.
framing.forYoungPeople: Stop the debt trap. Make colleges compete on value, not access to government money.
framing.forTaxpayers: Why should plumbers subsidize philosophy degrees with poor job outcomes?

subPolicies.allies: Fiscal conservatives, vocational education advocates, some young people
subPolicies.opposition: Universities, student loan industry, progressive advocates

policies.title: Social Security Reform
policies.description: Save Social Security for current retirees while giving younger workers better options.

subPolicies.title: Voluntary Private Accounts for Younger Workers
problem: Social Security returns are negative for younger workers
Trust fund going broke
No ownership or inheritance of contributions
Younger workers pay for current retirees with no guarantee
positions: Allow workers under 40 to opt into private retirement accounts
Keep Social Security for current and near-retirees
Private accounts earn market returns and are inheritable
Guarantee safety net for those who opt in
Transition over decades
subPolicies.framing: Younger workers deserve ownership and better returns. Reform now to save the system.

subPolicies.title: Means Testing & Benefit Adjustments
problem: Wealthy retirees receive full benefits
System unsustainable without changes
Benefits exceed contributions for high earners
positions: Reduce benefits for wealthy retirees (means testing)
Raise retirement age for younger workers
Adjust cost-of-living formulas
Protect benefits for low- and middle-income retirees
Phase in changes gradually
subPolicies.framing: Tough choices now prevent collapse later. Protect those who need it most.

policies.title: Tax Reform
policies.description: Simplify the tax code, lower rates, and eliminate special-interest loopholes.

subPolicies.title: Flat or Consumption Tax
problem: Complex tax code favors those who can afford accountants
Loopholes and carve-outs distort economy
Income tax punishes productivity
IRS enforcement burdens ordinary taxpayers
positions: Replace income tax with flat tax or national sales tax (FairTax)
Abolish IRS or drastically reduce its size
Universal deduction to protect low earners
Eliminate all deductions and credits
Simplicity and transparency
subPolicies.framing: Tax everyone fairly at the same rate. No more loopholes, no more IRS abuses.

subPolicies.title: Eliminate Carve-Outs & Special Interests
problem: Tax code riddled with special-interest breaks
Corporations and wealthy exploit loopholes
Complexity hides handouts
Ordinary taxpayers pay more
positions: Eliminate all corporate tax breaks and subsidies
No targeted tax credits for specific industries
Lower rates, broaden base
Treat all income equally (wages, capital gains, dividends)
Transparency in tax expenditures
subPolicies.framing: Lower rates for everyone—not special deals for insiders. Simplify and level the playing field.

policies.title: Drug Policy Reform
policies.description: End the failed war on drugs with evidence-based policies focused on treatment and liberty.

subPolicies.title: Decriminalize & Focus on Treatment
problem: War on drugs has failed for 50 years
Mass incarceration without reducing use
Ruined lives over nonviolent offenses
Lack of treatment options
positions: Decriminalize personal drug possession
Expand treatment and recovery programs
Expunge nonviolent drug offenses
Focus enforcement on trafficking and violence
Treat addiction as health issue, not crime
subPolicies.framing: Locking people up for addiction doesn't work. Treatment saves lives.

subPolicies.title: Marijuana Legalization
problem: Federal prohibition despite state legalization
Arrests for marijuana use continue
Lost tax revenue and economic opportunity
Inconsistent laws create confusion
positions: Legalize marijuana at federal level
Expunge marijuana convictions
Tax and regulate like alcohol
Allow states to set own policies
End federal interference in state-legal marijuana
subPolicies.framing: Marijuana prohibition has failed. Legalize, regulate, and tax it.

policies.title: Housing Reform
policies.description: Address the housing affordability crisis through deregulation and market-based solutions.

subPolicies.title: Zoning & Land Use Reform
problem: Restrictive zoning limits housing supply
Single-family-only zoning in most areas
NIMBYism blocks new development
Housing costs soar as supply constrained
positions: Legalize multi-family and accessory dwelling units (ADUs)
Reduce minimum lot sizes and setback requirements
Expedite permitting for housing
Override exclusionary zoning
Let supply meet demand
subPolicies.framing: Build more housing, lower the cost. Zoning rules make housing unaffordable.

subPolicies.title: Reduce Construction Costs & Regulations
problem: Excessive building codes raise costs
Environmental reviews delay projects for years
Prevailing wage laws increase expenses
Regulatory compliance adds 20-30% to costs
positions: Streamline building codes—adopt model codes
Expedite environmental reviews for housing
Reform or eliminate prevailing wage mandates
Allow innovative construction methods (modular, 3D printing)
Cut red tape to lower costs
subPolicies.framing: Regulations price people out of homes. Cut the red tape and build.
